mortality.note: Estimates range from 90,000 to 2 million. Mongol sources claim 200,000; Arab historians claim over 1 million. Siege lasted 2 weeks, massacre lasted 7 days. Caliph Al-Musta'sim executed. Death toll includes scholars, scientists, and religious leaders systematically killed.

rationales.systematic_intensity: Deliberate destruction of libraries and cultural institutions. House of Wisdom destroyed. Books thrown into Tigris until river ran black with ink. Irrigation systems destroyed, ending centuries of agricultural prosperity.
rationales.profit: Massive plunder of Abbasid treasury. Gold, jewels, and artifacts seized. Economic infrastructure deliberately destroyed to prevent recovery.
rationales.ideology: Mongol ultimatum rejected; punishment was total destruction as per Mongol doctrine. No religious purification motive - Mongols were religiously tolerant.
rationales.complicity: Christian and Shia minorities assisted Mongols due to grievances with Sunni Caliphate. Neighboring powers did not intervene.

analysis.pattern_note: Marks the end of the Islamic Golden Age. The House of Wisdom - containing works of mathematics, astronomy, medicine, and philosophy from Greek, Persian, Indian, and Islamic scholars - was destroyed. Survivors reported the Tigris ran black with ink from books and red with blood. Irrigation canals destroyed, turning fertile land to desert. Baghdad would not recover its pre-1258 population until the 20th century. One of history's greatest cultural catastrophes.
analysis.root_causes: Mongol expansion, Abbasid weakness and isolation, Hulagu's personal ambition to end Caliphate
